awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Quantification of Gravity Wave Momentum Fluxes and Instability Events in the Mesosphere and Lower Thermosphere (MLT) Region at High- and Mid- Latitudes
awd_abstract_narration:
This project involves comprehensive observational studies, guided by state-of-the-art modeling, to quantify gravity wave (GW) momentum transport and the instability dynamics that drive energy and momentum deposition and GW spectral evolution in the mesosphere and lower thermosphere (MLT) region. The observations will build on recent successes by this team employing an Advanced Mesosphere Temperature Mapper (AMTM), the Weber Wind and Temperature sodium lidar, and other correlative instrumentation operated at the Arctic Lidar Observatory for Middle Atmosphere Research (ALOMAR) in northern Norway (69.3oN). These earlier correlative measurement capabilities have demonstrated an excellent potential to quantify GW momentum fluxes, and the GW characteristics that account for these fluxes, to a degree not possible with traditional airglow imagers or wind profiling radars or lidars. As such, this program represents a new frontier in the community's ability to measure, explore and understand small-scale GW and instability dynamics in the MLT that directly impact the Space-Atmospheric Interaction Region (SAIR) of prime importance to the NSF Aeronomy and CEDAR programs.  

These studies will continue to employ the high-quality correlative wintertime measurement capabilities at ALOMAR and will include extensive summertime Na lidar and AMTM measurement capability recently available at Bear Lake Observatory (BLO) and the nearby Utah State University (USU) campus (41.9oN). Together these two data sets will provide an excellent measure of the different geophysical forcing effects on the high- and mid-latitude MLT region. These facilities provide the best potential for multiple correlative data sets, given the on-site access to lidar operators. These proven measurement capabilities will also facilitate estimates of the spatial and temporal scales of the GW packets, accounting for mean forcing and the generation of secondary GWs, which are largely unknown at present, but are needed for understanding and parameterizing GW effects in weather, climate, and general circulation models addressing both research and societal needs. The measurements from these two stations, if successful, will provide the necessary inputs for a realistic model development.

por.por_cntn:
This research grant has supported novel collaborative studies of ?weather? induced wave events, colloquially termed ?gravity waves? in the Earth?s high-latitude upper atmosphere.  Our measurements were made from the ALOMAR Arctic Lidar Observatory, at Andenes, in northern Norway (69?N). ALOMAR is a well-established international observatory supporting optical, radar and rocket-borne measurements of a broad range of atmospheric phenomena including the beautiful ?Northern Lights? (or ?Aurora Borealis?), which occur frequently within the Arctic circle. At USU?s Space Dynamics Laboratory (SDL), we have developed a new camera, called an Advanced Mesospheric Temperature Mapper (AMTM), capable of measuring the gravity waves in infrared light where they are bright and can be easily detected even in the presence of visible aurora.

Gravity waves (GW) are a naturally occurring atmospheric phenomenon generated by strong weather disturbances, such as fronts, storms and intense winds blowing over high mountain ranges, such as the Scandinavian Mountain Range. They are important as they can transfer large amounts of energy upwards into the atmosphere when they break, like waves on a beach, strongly affecting the ?weather? in the upper atmosphere where future space planes will fly.    At lower altitudes, gravity wave breaking creates the unsettling, and sometimes dangerous, turbulence felt by passengers flying over mountainous regions.  

Our studies have achieved the primary goals. The AMTM was deployed and successfully operated at ALOMAR for several winter seasons to study the properties and sources of gravity waves at polar latitudes.  Automatic observations were made continuously at night as the waves propagated into the upper levels of the Earth?s atmosphere (called the ?mesosphere? at an altitude of about 87 km, or 50 miles).  Our analyses to date have yielded the following key results. (a) First detection and measurements of mesospheric mountain waves (MWs) over northern Scandinavia associated with strong tropospheric wind forcing, (b) established Arctic wintertime gravity wave climatology and its variability using several consecutive winter seasons data, (c) determination of very large GW momentum flux events using coordinated AMTM and radar wind data, and (d) first comparison of Arctic and Antarctic GW variances establishing similar magnitudes and winter time variability in both hemispheres.  

This collaborative research has supported three completed Ph.D. student programs (one US Native American student, one US female student, and one international student). In addition, two further international students are using these data for their Ph.D. programs, in progress.
